The fits o'th' Season. I dare not speak much further,
But cruel are the Times; when we are Traytors,
And do not know our selves: when we hold Rumor,
From what we fear, yet know not what we fear;
But float upon a wild and violent Sea.
Each way, and more, I take my way of you:
'T shall not be long but I'll be here again.
Things at the worst will cease, or else climb upwards
To what they were before. Heaven protect you.

sp.speaker: Lady Mad.
sp.l: Farewell Sir.

sp.speaker: Wom.
sp.l: Madam, a Gentleman in haste desires
To speak with you.

sp.speaker: Lady Md.
sp.l: A Gentleman, admit him. Enter Seyton.

sp.speaker: Seyton.
sp.l: Though I have not the honour to be known
To you, Yet I was well acquainted with
The Lord Macduff which brings me here to tell you
There's danger near you, be not found here,
Fly with your little one; Heaven preserve you,
I dare stay no longer. Exit Seyton.

sp.speaker: Lady Md.
sp.l: Where shall I go, and whither shall I fly?
I've done no harm; but I remember now
I'm in a vicious world, where to do harm
Is often prosperous, and to do good
Accounted dangerous folly; Why do I then
Make use of this so womanly defence?
I'le boldly in, and dare this new Alarm:
What need they fear whom Innocense doth arm? Exit.

div.stage: Enter Malcolm, and Macduff. The Scene Birnam Wood.

sp.speaker: Macd.
sp.l: In these close shades of Birnam Wood let us
Weep our sad Bosoms empty.

sp.speaker: Malcolm.
sp.l: You'l think my Fortunes desperate,
That I dare meet you here upon your summons.

sp.speaker: Macd.
sp.l: You should now
Take Arms to serve your Country. Each new day
New Widows mourn, new Orphans cry, and still
Changes of sorrow reach attentive Heaven.

sp.speaker: Malc.
sp.l: This Tirant whose foul Name blisters our Tongues,
Was once thought, honest. You have lov'd him well.
He has not toucht you yet.

sp.speaker: Macd.
sp.l: I am not treacherous.

sp.speaker: Malc.
sp.l: But Macbeth is.
And yet Macduff may be what I did always think him,
Just, and good.

sp.speaker: Macd.
sp.l: I've lost my hopes.

sp.speaker: Malc.
sp.l: Perhaps even there where I did find my doubts;
But let not Jealousies be your Dishonours,
But my own safeties.

sp.speaker: Macd.
sp.l: Bleed, Bleed, poor Country.
Great Tiranny, lay thy Foundation sure,
Villains are safe when good men are suspected.
I'le say no more. Fare thee well young Prince,
I would not be that Traytor which thou thinkst me
For twice Macbeths reward of Treachery.

sp.speaker: Malc.
sp.l: Be not offended:
I speak not as in absolute fear of you:
I think our Countrey sinks beneath the Yoak,
It weeps, it bleeds, and each new day a gash
Is added to her wounds. I think withall
That many hands would in my Cause be active.
And here from gracious England have I offer
Of goodly Thousands. But for all this,
When I shall tread upon the Tirants head,
Or wear it on my Sword; yet my poor Country
Will suffer under greater Tiranny
Than what it suffers now,

sp.speaker: Macd.
sp.l: It cannot be.

sp.speaker: Malc.
sp.l: Alas I find my Nature so inclin'd
To Vice, that foul Macbeth when I shall rule,
Will seem as white as Snow.

sp.speaker: Macd.
sp.l: There cannot in all ransackt Hell be found
A Devil equal to Macbeth.

sp.speaker: Malc.
sp.l: I grant him bloody false, deceiptful malitious,
And participating in some sins too horrid to name;
But there's no bottom, no depths in my ill appetite,
If such a one be fit to govern, speak?

sp.speaker: Macd.
sp.l: O Scotlond, Scotland, when shalt thou see day again?
Since that the truest Issue of thy Throne,
Disclaims his Virtue to avoid thy Crown?
Your Royal Father
Was a most Saint-like King; the Queen that bore you,
Oftner upon her Knees, than on her Feet,
Dy'd every day she liv'd. Fare thee well,
These Evils thou repeat'st upon thy self,
Hath banisht me from Scotland. O my breast!
Thy hope ends here.

sp.speaker: Malc.
sp.l: Macduff this Noble Passion
Child of Integrity hath from my Soul
Wip'd the black scruples, reconcil'd my Thoughts
To thy good truth and honour. Macbeth
By many of these Trains hath sought to win me
Into his Power: And modest wisdom plucks me
From over-credulous haste. But now
I put my self to thy direction, and
Unspeak mine own Detraction. I abjure
The taunts and blames I laid upon my self,
For strangers to my Nature. What I am truly
Is thine, and my poor Countreys to command.
The gracious Edward has lent us Seymour,
And ten thousand Men. Why are you silent?

sp.speaker: Macd.
sp.l: Such welcom and unwelcom things at once
Are Subjects for my Wonder not my Speech,
My grief and Joy contesting in my bosom,
I find that I can scarce my tongue command,
When two Streams meet the Water's at a stand.

sp.speaker: Malc.
sp.l: Assistance granted by that pious King
Must be successful, he who by his touch,
Can cure our Bodies of a foul Disease,
Can by just force suddue a Traitors Mind,
Power supernatural is unconfin'd.

sp.speaker: Macd.
sp.l: If his Compassion does on Men Diseas'd
Effect such Cures; What Wonders will he do,
When to Compassion he ads Justice too? Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Macb.
sp.l: Seaton, go bid the Army March.

sp.speaker: Seat.
sp.l: The posture of Affairs requires your Presence.

sp.speaker: Macb.
sp.l: But the Indosposition of my Wife
Detains me here.

sp.speaker: Seat.
sp.l: Th'Enemy is upon our borders, Scotland's in danger.

sp.speaker: Macb:
sp.l: So is my Wife, and I am doubly so.
I am sick in her, and my Kingdom too.

sp.speaker: Seaton.
sp.l: Sir,

sp.speaker: Macb.
sp.l: The Spur of my Ambition prompts me to go
And make my Kingdom safe; but Love which softens me
To pity her in her distress, curbs my Resolves.

sp.speaker: Seat.
sp.l: He's strangely disorder'd.

sp.speaker: Macb.
sp.l: Yet why should Love since confin'd, desire
To controul Ambition, for whose spreading hopes
The world's too narrow, It shall not; Great Fires
Put out the Less; Seaton go bid my Grooms
Make ready; Ile not delay my going.

sp.speaker: Seat.
sp.l: I go.

sp.speaker: Macb.
sp.l: Stay Seaton, stay, Compassion calls me back.

sp.speaker: Seaton.
sp.l: He looks and moves disorderly.

sp.speaker: Macb.
sp.l: I'le not go yet. Enter a Servant, who whispers Macbeth

sp.speaker: Seat.
sp.l: Well Sir.

sp.speaker: Macb.
sp.l: Is the Queen asleep?

sp.speaker: Seat.
sp.l: What makes 'em whisper and his countenance change?
Perhaps some new design has had ill success.

sp.speaker: Macb.
sp.l: Seaton, Go see what posture our Affairs are in.

sp.speaker: Seat.
sp.l: I shall, and give you notice Sir. Exit Seat.

sp.speaker: Macb.
sp.l: How does my Gentle Love?

sp.speaker: Lady Mb.
sp.l: Duncan is dead.

sp.speaker: Macb.
sp.l: No words of that.

sp.speaker: Lady Mb.
sp.l: And yet to Me he Lives.
His fatal Ghost is now my shadow, and pursues me
Where e're I go.

sp.speaker: Macb.
sp.l: It cannot be My Dear,
Your Fears have misinform'd your eyes.

sp.speaker: Lady Mb.
sp.l: See there; Believe your own.
Why do you follow Me? I did not do it.

sp.speaker: Macb.
sp.l: Methinks there's nothing.

sp.speaker: Lady Mb.
sp.l: If you have Valour force him hence.
Hold, hold, he's gone. Now you look strangely.

sp.speaker: Macb.
sp.l: 'Tis the strange error of your Eyes.

sp.speaker: Lady Mb.
sp.l: But the strange error of my Eyes
Proceeds from the strange Action of your Hands.
Distraction does by fits possess my head,
Because a Crown unjustly covers it.
I stand so high that I am giddy grown.
A Mist does cover me, as Clouds the tops
Of Hills. Let us get down apace.

sp.speaker: Macb.
sp.l: If by your high ascent you giddy grow,
'Tis when you cast your Eyes on things below.

sp.speaker: Lady Mb.
sp.l: You may in Peace resign the ill gain'd Crown.
Why should you labour still to be unjust?
There has been too much Blood already spilt.
Make not the Subjects Victims to your guilt.

sp.speaker: Macb.
sp.l: Can you think that a crime, which you did once
Provoke me to commit, had not your breath
Blown my Ambition up into a Flame
Duncan had yet been living▪

sp.speaker: Lady Mb.
sp.l: You were a Man.
And by the Charter of your Sex you shou'd
Have govern'd me, there was more crime in you
When you obey'd my Councels, then I contracted
By my giving it. Resign your Kingdom now,
And with your Crown put off your guilt.

sp.speaker: Macb.
sp.l: Resign the Crown, and with it both our Lives.
I must have better Councellors.

sp.speaker: Lady Mb.
sp.l: What, your Witches?
Curse on your Messengers of Hell. Their Breath
Infected first my Breast: See me no more.
As King your Crown sits heavy on your Head,
But heavier on my Heart: I have had too much
Of Kings already. See the Ghost again. Ghost appears.

sp.speaker: Macb.
sp.l: Now she relapses.

sp.speaker: Lady Mb.
sp.l: Speak to him if thou canst.
Thou look'st on me, and shew'st thy wounded breast.
Shew it the Murderer.

sp.speaker: Macb.
sp.l: Within there, Ho. Enter Women.

sp.speaker: Lady Mb.
sp.l: Am I ta'ne Prisoner? then the Battle's lost. Exit.

div.stage: Lady Macbeth led out by Women.

sp.speaker: Macb.
sp.l: She does from Duncans death to sickness grieve,
And shall from Malcoms death her health receive.
When by a Viper bitten, nothing's good
To cure the venom but a Vipers blood.

div.stage: Enter Malcom, Macduff; and Lenox, Meeting them.

sp.speaker: Macd.
sp.l: See who comes here!

sp.speaker: Malc.
sp.l: My Countrey-man; but yet I know him not.

sp.speaker: Macd.
sp.l: My ever Gentle Couzin! Welcom.

sp.speaker: Malc.
sp.l: I know him now.
Kind Heaven remove the Means that makes us strangers.

sp.speaker: Len.
sp.l: Amen.

sp.speaker: Macd.
sp.l: What looks does Scotland bear?

sp.speaker: Len.
sp.l: Alas poor Countrey, almost afraid to know it self.
It can't be call'd our Mother but our Grave; where nothing,
But who knows nothing is once seen to smile?
Where sighs, and groans, and shrieks that rend the air,
Are made, not mark'd, where violent sorrow seems
A Modern Extasie: there Bells
Are always ringing, and no Man asks for whom;
There good Mens lives expire e're they sicken.

sp.speaker: Macd.
sp.l: Oh Relation! too nice, and yet too true.

sp.speaker: Malc.
sp.l: What's the newest grief?

sp.speaker: Len.
sp.l: That of an hours age is out of date,
Each Minute brings a new one.

sp.speaker: Macd.
sp.l: How does my Wife?

sp.speaker: Len.
sp.l: Why well.

sp.speaker: Macd.
sp.l: And all my Children?

sp.speaker: Len.
sp.l: Well too.

sp.speaker: Macd.
sp.l: The Tirant has not quarrell'd at their peace?

sp.speaker: Len.
sp.l: No, they were well at peace when I left 'em

sp.speaker: Macd.
sp.l: Be not so sparing of your speech. How goe'st?

sp.speaker: Len.
sp.l: When I came hither to transport the tidings,
Which I have heavily born, there ran a rumour
Of many Worthy Men that rose into a head,
Which was to my Belief; witness the rather,
For that I saw the Tirants Power a foot.
Now, is the time of help; your Eye in Scotland
Would create Soldiers, and make Women fight.

sp.speaker: Malc.
sp.l: Be't their Comfort,
We are coming thither: Gracious England hath
Lent us good Seymour, and ten thousand Men.

sp.speaker: Len.
sp.l: Wou'd I cou'd answer this comfort with the like;
But I have words,
That would be utter'd in the desart air,
Where no Mans ear should hear'em.

sp.speaker: Macd.
sp.l: What concern they? the general cause,
Or is't a grief due to some single breast?

sp.speaker: Len:
sp.l: All honest Minds must share in't;
But the main part pertains to you.

sp.speaker: Macd:
sp.l: If it be mine, keep it not from Me.

sp.speaker: Len:
sp.l: Let not your ears condemn my tongue for ever,
When they shall possess them with the heaviest sound
That ever yet they heard.

sp.speaker: Macd:
sp.l: At once I guess, yet am afraid to know,

sp.speaker: Len:
sp.l: Your Castle is surpriz'd, your Wife and Children.
Savagely Murder'd: to relate the Manner,
Were to increase the Butchery of them,
By adding to their fall the Death of You.

sp.speaker: Malc:
sp.l: Merciful Heaven! Noble Macduff
Give sorrow words; the grief that does not speak,
Whispers the o're charg'd heart, and bids it break.

sp.speaker: Macd:
sp.l: My Children too?

sp.speaker: Len:
sp.l: Your Wife, and both your Children,

sp.speaker: Macd:
sp.l: And I not with them dead? Both, both my Children
Did you say; my Two?

sp.speaker: Len:
sp.l: I have said,

sp.speaker: Macd:
sp.l: Be comforted;
Let's make us Cordials of our great Revenues,
To cure this deadly Grief.

sp.speaker: Macd:
sp.l: He has no Children, nor can he feel
A fathers Grief: Did you say all my Children?
Oh hellish ravenous Kite! all three at one swoop!

sp.speaker: Malc:
sp.l: Dispute it like a Man.

sp.speaker: Macd:
sp.l: I shall.
But I must first too feel it as a Man.
I cannot but remember such things were,
And were most precious to me: Did Heaven look on,
And would not take their part? sinful Macduff,
They were all struck for thee; for thee they fell:
Not for their own offences; but for thine.

sp.speaker: Malc:
sp.l: Let this give Edges to our Swords; let your tears
Become Oyl to our kindled Rage.

sp.speaker: Macd:
sp.l: Oh I could play the Woman with my Eyes,
And brag on't with my tongue; kind Heavens bring this
Dire Friend of Scotland, and my self face to face,
And set him within the reach of my keen Sword.
And if he outlives that hour, may Heaven forgive
His sins, and punish Me for his escape.

sp.speaker: Malc:
sp.l: Let's hasten to the Army, since Macbeth
Is ripe for fall.

sp.speaker: Macd.
sp.l: Heaven give our quarrel but as good success
As it hath Justice in't: Kind Powers above
Grant Peace to us, whilst we take his away;
The Night is long that never finds a Day. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Lady:
sp.l: I have seen her rise from her bed, throw
Her Night-Gown on her, unlock her Closet,
Take forth Paper, fold it, write upon't, read it,
Afterwards Seal it, and again return to Bed,
Yet all this while in a most fast sleep.

sp.speaker: Seat:
sp.l: 'Tis strange she should receive the Benefit
Of sleep, and do the Effects of waking.
In this disorder what at any time have
You heard her say?

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: That Sir, which I will not report of her.

sp.speaker: Seat:
sp.l: You may to Me; and 'tis most meet you shou'd.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: Neither to You, nor any one living;
Having no witness to confirm my Speech.
See here she comes: observe her, and stand close.

sp.speaker: Seat.
sp.l: You see her eyes are open.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: Ay, But her Sense is shut.

sp.speaker: Seat.
sp.l: What is't she does now? look how she rubs her hands:

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: It is an accustom'd action with her to seem
Thus washing her hands: I have known
Her continue in this a quarter of an hour.

sp.speaker: Lady Mb.
sp.l: Yet out, out, here's a spot.

sp.speaker: Seat.
sp.l: Heark, she speaks.

sp.speaker: Lady Mb.
sp.l: Out, out, out I say. One, two: Nay then
'Tis time to do't: Fy my Lord, fy, a Soldier,
And affraid? what need we fear? who knows it?
There's none dares call our Power to account;
Yet who would have thought the old Man had
So much Blood in him.

sp.speaker: Seat.
sp.l: Do you mark that?

sp.speaker: Lady Mb.
sp.l: Macduff had once a Wife; where is she now?
Will these Hands n'ere be clean? Fy my Lord,
You spoil all with this starting: Yet here's
A smell of blood; not all the perfumes of Arabia
Will sweeten this little Hand. Oh, Oh, Oh.

div.head: Scen. II.
div.stage: Enter Donalbain and Flean, met by Lenox.

sp.speaker: Len.
sp.l: Is not that DONALBAIN and young Flean, Banquo's Son.

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.l: Who is this my worthy Friend?

sp.speaker: Len.
sp.l: I by your presence feel my hopes full blown,
Which hitherto have been but in the Bud.
What happy gale has brought you here to see
Your Fathers Death Reveng'd?

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.l: Hearing of aid sent by the English King,
To check the Tirants Insolence; I am come
From Ireland:

sp.speaker: Flea.
sp.l: And I from France, we are but newly met.

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.l: Where's my Brother?

sp.speaker: Len.
sp.l: He and the Good Macduff are with the Army
Behind the Wood.

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.l: What do's the Tyrant now?

sp.speaker: Len.
sp.l: He strongly Fortifies in Dunsinane;
Some say he is Mad, others who Love him less,
Call it a Valiant Fury; but what e're
The matter is, there is a Civil War
Within his Bosom; and he finds his Crown
Sit loose about him: His Power grows less,
His Fear grows greater still.

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.l: Let's haste and meet my Brother,
My Interest is Grafted into his,
And cannot Grow without it.

sp.speaker: Len.
sp.l: So may you both Out-grow unlucky Chance,
And may the Tyrant's Fall that Growth Advance.

sp.speaker: Macb.
sp.l: Bring me no more Reports: Let 'em flie all
Till Byrnam Wood remove to Dunsinane
I cannot fear. What's the Boy Malcome? What
Are all the English? Are they not of Women
Born? And t'all such I am Invincible,
Then flie false Thanes,
By your Revolt you have inflam'd my Rage,
And now have Borrowed English Blood to quench it.
Now Friend, what means thy change of Countenance?

sp.speaker: Mess.
sp.l: There are Ten Thousand, Sir,

sp.speaker: Macb.
sp.l: What, Ghosts?

sp.speaker: Mess.
sp.l: No, Armed men.

sp.speaker: Macb.
sp.l: But such as shall be Ghosts e're it be Night.
Art thou turn'd Coward too, since I made thee Captain:
Go Blush away thy Paleness, I am sure
Thy Hands are of another Colour; thou hast Hands
Of Blood, but Looks of Milk.

sp.speaker: Mess.
sp.l: The English Force so please you—???

sp.speaker: Macb.
sp.l: Take thy Face hence.
He has Infected me with Fear
I am sure to die by none of Woman morn.
And yet the English Drums beat an Alarm,
As fatal to my Life as are the Crokes
Of Ravens, when they Flutter about the Windows
Of departing men.
My Hopes are great, and yet me-thinks I fear
My Subjects cry out Curses on my Name,
Which like a North-wind seems to blast my Hopes:

sp.speaker: Seat.
sp.l: That Wind is a contagious Vapour exhal'd from Blood.
What News more?

sp.speaker: 2. Mess.
sp.l: All's confirm'd my Leige, that was Reported.

sp.speaker: Macb.
sp.l: And my Resolves in spite of Fate shall be as firmly.
Send out more Horse; and Scour the Country round.
How do's my Wife?

sp.speaker: Seat.
sp.l: Not so Sick, my Lord, as She is Troubled
With disturbing Fancies, that keep Her from Her rest.

sp.speaker: Macb.
sp.l: And I, me-thinks, am Sick of her Disease:
Seaton send out; Captain, the Thanes flie from thee:
Wou'd she were well, I'de quickly win the Field.
Stay Seaton, stay, I'le bear you company,
The English cannot long maintain the Fight;
They come not here to Kill, but to be Slain;
Send out our Scouts.

sp.speaker: Seat.
sp.l: Sir, I am gone.
Aside Not to Obey your Orders, but the Call of Justice.
I'le to the English Train whose Hopes are built
Upon their Cause, and not on Witches Prophesies. Exit.

sp.speaker: Macb.
sp.l: Poor Thanes, you vainly hope for Victory:
You'l find Macbeth Invincible; or if
He can be O'recome, it must be then
By Birnam Oaks, and not by English-men. Exit.

div.head: Scen. IV.
div.stage: Enter Malcom, Donalbain, Seymor, Macduff, Lenox, Flean, Souldiers.

sp.speaker: Malc.
sp.l: The Sun shall see us Drain the Tyrants Blood
And Dry up Scotlands Tears: How much we are
Oblig'd to England, which like a kind Neighbour
Lift's us up when we were Fall'n below
Our own Recovery.

sp.speaker: Seym.
sp.l: What Wood is this before us?

sp.speaker: Malc.
sp.l: The Wood of Birnam.

sp.speaker: Seym.
sp.l: Let every Souldier hew him down a Bough,
And bear't before him: By that we may
Keep the Number of our Force undiscover'd
By the Enemy.

sp.speaker: Malc.
sp.l: It shall be done. We Learn no more then that
The Confident Tyrant keeps still in Dunsinane,
And will endure a Seige.
He is of late grown Conscious of his Guilt,
Which makes him make that City his Place of Refuge.

sp.speaker: Macd.
sp.l: He'l find even there but little Safety;
His very Subjects will aginst him Rise.
So Travellers Flie to an Aged Barn
For Shelter from the Rain; when the next Shock
Of Wind throws Down that Roof upon their Heads,
From which they hop'd for Succour.

sp.speaker: Len.
sp.l: The wretched Kernes which now like Boughs are ty'd
To forc'd Obedience; will when our Swords
Have Cut those Bonds, start from Obedience.

sp.speaker: Malc.
sp.l: May the Event make good our Guess:

sp.speaker: Macd.
sp.l: It must, unless our Resolutions fail
They'l kindle, Sir, their just Revenge at ours:
Which double Flame will Singe the Wings of all
The Tyrants hopes; depriv'd of those Supports,
He'l quickly Fall.

sp.speaker: Seym.
sp.l: Let's all Retire to our Commands; our Breath
Spent in Discourse does but defer his Death,
And but delays our Vengeance,

sp.speaker: Macd.
sp.l: Come let's go.
The swiftest hast is for Revenge too slow. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Macb.
sp.l: Hang out our Banners proudly o're the Wall,
The Cry is still, they Come: Our Castles Strength
Will Laugh a Siege to Scorn: Here let them lie
Till Famine eat them up: Had Seaton still
Been ours, and others who now Increase the Number
Of our Enemies, we might have met 'em
Face to Face. Noise within.
What Noise is that?

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: It seems the Cry of Women.

sp.speaker: Macb.
sp.l: I have almost forgot the Taste of Fears,
The time has been that Dangers have been my Familiars.
Wherefore was that Cry?

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: Great, Sir, the Queen is Dead.

sp.speaker: Macb.
sp.l: She should have Di'd hereafter,
I brought Her here, to see my Victines, not to Die.
To Morrow, to Morrow, and to Morrow,
Creeps in a stealing pace from Day to Day,
To the last Minute of Recorded Time:
And all our Yesterdays have lighted Fools
To their Eternal Homes: Out, out that Candle,
Life's but a Walking Shaddow, a poor Player
That Struts and Frets his Hour upon the Stage,
And then is Heard no more. It is a Tale
Told by an Ideot, full of Sound and Fury
Signifying Nothing. Enter a Messenger.
Thou comest to use thy Tongue: Thy Story quickly.

sp.speaker: Mess.
sp.l: Let my Eyes speak what they have seen,
For my Tongue cannot.

sp.speaker: Macb.
sp.l: Thy Eyes speak Terror, let thy Tongue expound,
Their Language, or be for ever Dumb.

sp.speaker: Mess.
sp.l: As I did stand my Watch upon the Hill,
I lookt towards Birnam, and anon me thoughts
The Wood began to move:

sp.speaker: Macb.
sp.l: Lyar and Slave.

sp.speaker: Mess.
sp.l: Let me endure your Wrath if't be not so:
Within this three Mile may you see it coming,
I say, a moving Grove.

sp.speaker: Macb.
sp.l: If thou speakst False, I'll send thy Soul
To th' other World to meet with moving Woods,
And walking Forrests;
There to Possess what it but Dreamt of here.
If thy Speech be true, I care not if thou doest
The same for me. I now begin
To doubt the Equivocation of the Fiend,
They bid me not to fear till Birnam Wood
Should come to Dansinane: And now a Wood
Is on its March this way; Arm, Arm.
Since thus a Wood do's in a March appear,
There is no Flying hence, nor Tarrying here:
Methinks I now grow weary of the Sun,
And wish the Worlds great Glass of Life were run.

div.head: Scene. VI.
div.stage: Enter Malcome, Seymour, Macduff, Lenox, Flean, Seaton, Donalbain, and their Army with Boughs.

sp.speaker: Malc:
sp.l: Here we are near enough; throw down
Your Leafie Skreens
And shew like those you are. You worthy Uncle
Shall with my Brother and the Noble Lenox,
March in the Van, whilst Valiant Seymour
And my Self, make up the Gross of the Army,
And follow you with speed.

sp.speaker: Sey.
sp.l: Fare well; the Monster has forsook his hold and comes
To offer Battle.

sp.speaker: Macd:
sp.l: Let him come on; his Title now
Sits Loose about him, like a Giants Robe
Upon a Dwarfish Thief.

sp.speaker: Macb.
sp.l: 'Tis too Ignoble, and too base to Flie;
Who's he that is not of a Woman Born,
For such a one I am to fear, or none.

sp.speaker: Len.
sp.l: Kind Heaven, I thank thee; have I found thee here;
Oh Scotland! Scotland! mayst thou owe thy just
Revenge to this sharp Sword, or this blest Minute.

sp.speaker: Macb.
sp.l: Retire fond Man, I wou'd not Kill thee.
Why should Faulcons prey on Flies?
It is below Macbeth to Fight with Men.

sp.speaker: Len.
sp.l: But not to Murder Women.

sp.speaker: Macb.
sp.l: Lenox, I pitty thee; thy Arm's too weak.

sp.speaker: Len:
sp.l: This Arm has hitherto found good Success
On your Ministers of Blood, who Murder'd
Macduffs Lady, and brave Banquo:
Art thou less Mortal then they were? Or more
Exempt from Punishment? Because thou most
Deserv'st it. Have at thy Life.

sp.speaker: Macb:
sp.l: Since then thou art in Love with Death, I will
Vouchsafe it thee. They fight, Lenox falls.
Thou art of Woman Born, I'm sure. Exit Macb.

sp.speaker: Len:
sp.l: Oh my dear Country, Pardon me that I,
Do in a Cause so great, so quickly Die. Dies.

sp.speaker: Macd:
sp.l: This way the Noise is, Tyrant shew thy Face,
If thou be'st Slain and by no hand of Mine,
My Wife and Childrens Ghosts will haunt me for't.
I cannot Strike
At wretched Slaves, who sell their Lives for Pay;
No, my Revenge shall seek a Nobler Prey.
Through all the Paths of Death, I'le search him out:
Let me but find him, Fortune. Exit.

sp.speaker: Sey.
sp.l: This way, Great Sir, the Tyrants People Fight
With Fear as great as is his Guilt.

sp.speaker: Malc:
sp.l: See who Lies here; the Noble Lenox slain,
What Storm has brought this Blood over our
Rising hopes.

sp.speaker: Sey.
sp.l: Restrain your Passion, Sir, let's to our Men,
Those who in Noble Causes fall, deserve
Our Pitty, not our Sorrow.
I le bid some Body bear the Body further hence.

sp.speaker: Macb.
sp.l: Why should I play the Roman Fool and Fall,
On my own Sword, while I have living Foes
To Conquer; my Wounds shew better upon them.

sp.speaker: Macd.
sp.l: Turn Hell-Hound, Turn.

sp.speaker: Macb.
sp.l: Of all Men else, I have avoided Thee;
But get thee back, my Soul is too much clog'd
With Blood of thine already.

sp.speaker: Macd.
sp.l: I'le have no Words, thy Villanies are worse
Then ever yet were Punisht with a Curse.

sp.speaker: Macb.
sp.l: Thou mayst as well attempt to Wound the Air,
As me; my Destiny's reserv'd for some Immortal Power,
And I must fall by Miracle; I cannot Bleed.

sp.speaker: Macd.
sp.l: Have thy black Deeds then turn'd thee to a Devil.

sp.speaker: Macb.
sp.l: Thou wouldst but share the Fate of Lenox.

sp.speaker: Macd.
sp.l: Is Lenox slain? and by a Hand that would Damn all it kills,
But thattheir Cause preserves 'em.

sp.speaker: Macb
sp.l: I have a Prophecy secures my Life.

sp.speaker: Macd.
sp.l: I have another which tells me I shall have his Blood,
Who first shed mine.

sp.speaker: Macb.
sp.l: None of Woman born can spill my Blood.

sp.speaker: Macd.
sp.l: Then let the Devils tell thee, Macduff
Was from his Mothers Womb untimely Ript.

sp.speaker: Macb.
sp.l: Curst be that Tongue that tells me so,
And double Damn'd be they who with a double sence
Make Promises to our Ears, and Break at last
That Promise to our sight: I will not Fight with thee.

sp.speaker: Macd.
sp.l: Then yield thy self a Prisoner to be Led about
The World, and Gaz'd on as a Monster, a Monster
More Deform'd then ever Ambition Fram'd,
Or Tyrannie could shape.

sp.speaker: Macb.
sp.l: I scorn to Yield. I will in spite of Enchantment
Fight with thee, though Birnam Wood be come
To Dunsinane:
And thou art of no Woman Born, I'le try,
If by a Man it be thy Fate to Die. They Fight, Macbeth falls. They shout within

sp.speaker: Macd.
sp.l: This for my Royal Master Duncan,
This for my dearest Friend my Wife,
This for those Pledges of our Loves, my Children.
Hark I hear a Noise, sure there are more Shout within.
Reserves to Conquer.
I'le as a Trophy bear away his Sword,
To witness my Revenge. Exit Macduff.

sp.speaker: Macb.
sp.l: Farewell vain World, and what's most vain in it,

div.stage: Enter Malcolm, Seymour, Donalbain, Flean, Seaton, and Souldiers.

sp.speaker: Malc.
sp.l: I wish Macduff were safe Arriv'd, I am
In doubt for him; for Lenox I'me in grief.

sp.speaker: Seym.
sp.l: Consider Lenox, Sir, is nobly Slain:
They who in Noble Causes fall, deserve
Our Pity, not our Sorrow. Look where the Tyrant is.

sp.speaker: Seat.
sp.l: The Witches, Sir, with all the Power of Hell,
Could not preserve him from the Hand of Heaven.

sp.speaker: Macd.
sp.l: Long Live Malcolm, King of Scotland, so you are;
And though I should not Boast, that one
Whom Guilt might easily weigh down, fell
By my Hand; yet here I present you with
The Tyrants Sword, to shew that Heaven appointed
Me to take Revenge for you, and all
That Suffered by his Power.

sp.speaker: Malc.
sp.l: Macduff, we have more Ancient Records
Then this of your successful Courage.

sp.speaker: Macd.
sp.l: Now Scotland, thou shalt see bright Day again,
That Cloud's remov'd that did Ecclipse thy Sun,
And Rain down Blood upon thee. As your Arms
Did all contribute to this Victory;
So let your Voices all concur to give
One joyful Acclamation.

l.hi: Long Live Malcolm, King of Scotland.

sp.speaker: Malc.
sp.l: We shall not make a large Expence of time
Before we Reckon with your several Loves,
And make us even with you. Thanes and Kinsman,
Henceforth be Earls, the first that ever Scotland
Saw Honour'd with that Title: And may they full Flourish
On your Families; though like the Laurels
You have Won to Day; they Spring from a Field of Blood.
Drag his Body hence, and let it Hang upon
A Pinnacle in Dunsinane, to shew
To shew to future Ages what to those is due,
Who others Right, by Lawless Power pursue.

sp.speaker: Macd.
sp.l: So may kind Fortune Crown your Raign with Peace,
As it has Crown'd your Armies with Success;
And may the Peoples Prayers still wait on you,
As all their Curses did Macbeth pursue:
His Vice shall make your Virtue shine more Bright,
As a Fair Day succeeds a Stormy Night.
